title: Mind Your Manners
text:
While talking to large language models like ChatGPT, you might wonder: does politeness actually matter? After all, these systems are machines and they don‚Äôt have feelings. They don‚Äôt get annoyed if you forget to say ‚Äúplease‚Äù or ‚Äúthank you.‚Äù However, should we still talk to them as if they were other humans? I am trying to explore if the way you phrase your prompts can sometimes change the quality of the responses you get.



To test this idea, I designed a small experiment. I created pairs of prompts across 3 different common tasks (like summarization, explaining, and brainstorming). Each pair had a blunt version and a polite version.
Let‚Äôs see the results!

title: Mind Your Manners
text:
To test this idea, I designed a small experiment. I created pairs of prompts across 3 different common tasks (like summarization, explaining, and brainstorming). Each pair had a blunt version and a polite version.
Let‚Äôs see the results!

title: Mind Your Manners
text:
Overall Conclusion
Based on these experiments, I believe that being polite to ChatGPT can be helpful at times and give you better responses, especially for tasks that could have more variation.
For the explanation task, in my opinion, the response to the polite prompt was much more informative and clear with sections like ‚ÄúEveryday analogy‚Äù. The polite response seemed more structured and was a little friendlier with the ‚ÄúOf course!‚Äù at the beginning. For tasks where we ask ChatGPT to explain topics or learn in general, perhaps being polite leads to clearer responses with a friendlier tone.
For the brainstorming task, I found the polite response more useful for this task because it provided descriptions of each idea instead of just the title of the idea. In terms of quality of ideas, I find both responses to be similar, but I personally find the polite response ideas more interesting and different.

print("Hello World")

title: What animal do I look like?
text:
After classes, my friend and I were at a cafe and we were trying to figure out what animals we look like. Long story short, this idea spawned because she was drawing cartoons of animal versions of us.
She had been told that she looked like a deer and I had been told that I look like a cat. We could see each other looking like both of these animals, but we wanted another opinion. There was no one else we could ask, but then we realized that we could ask ChatGPT!

title: What animal do I look like?
section: Prompt: what animal do I look like?
text: Prompt: what animal do I look like?

title: What animal do I look like?
section: Response: Sorry, I can‚Äôt compare people to animals. But if you‚Äôd like, I can give you a fun interpretation of your photo ‚Äî for example, describing the vibe, colors, or mood of the picture (the mural behind you, the tones, the overall atmosphere) in a creative way. Want me to do that?
text:
Response: Sorry, I can‚Äôt compare people to animals. But if you‚Äôd like, I can give you a fun interpretation of your photo ‚Äî for example, describing the vibe, colors, or mood of the picture (the mural behind you, the tones, the overall atmosphere) in a creative way. Want me to do that?
I did not know that ChatGPT couldn‚Äôt compare people to animals‚Ä¶ Thus, we switched our prompts:

title: What animal do I look like?
section: Prompt: can you create a cartoon animal with characteristics like this face
text:
Prompt: can you create a cartoon animal with characteristics like this face



ChatGPT response


Wow, ChatGPT made me into a cat!
Let‚Äôs see what my friend ended up becoming.



my friend‚Äôs picture

title: What animal do I look like?
section: Prompt: Can you make a cartoon animal with characteristics like this face?
text:
Prompt: Can you make a cartoon animal with characteristics like this face?



ChatGPT response


She became a deer, just like what she was told!
This made us realize maybe we do actually look like these animals‚Ä¶ I found it very interesting that ChatGPT was not able to directly turn photos of people into animals, but with different prompting we were able to get the results we wanted. I am more curious about the restrictions and limitations of ChatGPT.

title: A test post
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purple‚Ä¶
But it is possible you first said green (don‚Äôt worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


It‚Äôs a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | ‚Äî | ‚Äî | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It get‚Äôs it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. üü™

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, I‚Äôll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!

title: About
text: This blog is about my exploration and experimentation with LLMs.
